user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of consumer_thread:
```c
static void *consumer_thread(void *arg)
{
	(void)arg;
	metal_mutex_acquire(&lock);
	while (!counter)
		metal_condition_wait(&nempty_condv, &lock);
	counter--;
	metal_condition_signal(&nfull_condv);
	metal_mutex_release(&lock);

	return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function consumer_thread:
static unsigned int counter
...
METAL_MUTEX_DEFINE(lock)
...
static struct metal_condition nempty_condv = METAL_CONDITION_INIT
...
static struct metal_condition nfull_condv = METAL_CONDITION_INIT
...
int metal_condition_wait(struct metal_condition *cv,
				       metal_mutex_t *m)
{
	uintptr_t tmpmptr = 0, mptr = (uintptr_t)m;
	int v = 0;

	/* Check if the mutex has been acquired */
	if (!cv || !m || !metal_mutex_is_acquired(m))
		return -EINVAL;

	if (!atomic_compare_exchange_strong(&cv->mptr, &tmpmptr, mptr)) {
		if (tmpmptr != mptr)
			return -EINVAL;
	}

	v = atomic_load(&cv->wakeups);
	atomic_fetch_add(&cv->waiters, 1);

	/* Release the mutex before sleeping. */
	metal_mutex_release(m);
	syscall(SYS_futex, &cv->wakeups, FUTEX_WAIT, v, NULL, NULL, 0);
	atomic_fetch_sub(&cv->waiters, 1);
	/* Acquire the mutex after it's waken up. */
	metal_mutex_acquire(m);

	return 0;
}
...
static void *producer_thread(void *arg)
{
	(void)arg;
	metal_mutex_acquire(&lock);
	while (counter == COUNTER_MAX)
		metal_condition_wait(&nfull_condv, &lock);
	counter++;
	metal_condition_signal(&nempty_condv);
	metal_mutex_release(&lock);

	return NULL;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I did not find any code fragments that are necessarily unreachable (i.e., statically or logically impossible to reach) in the provided code. Reasoning by function:

- consumer_thread / producer_thread: Each thread acquires the mutex, enters a conditional while loop that calls metal_condition_wait only while the condition holds, performs the counter update, signals the other condition variable, releases the mutex, and returns. None of these statements are after an unconditional infinite loop or unconditional return that would make following code unreachable. The while loops are conditional and may block at runtime, but blocking is not the same as compile-time unreachable code.

- metal_condition_wait: All branches are reachable depending on runtime conditions. The early return on invalid parameters or if the mutex is not acquired (return -EINVAL) is reachable if callers pass invalid arguments or misuse the API. The atomic_compare_exchange_strong call can both succeed and fail; if it fails it updates tmpmptr, and the subsequent inner if (tmpmptr != mptr) may be true (causing return -EINVAL) or false (allowing execution to continue). The code that releases the mutex, calls futex wait, and reacquires the mutex is executed on the normal wait path and is therefore reachable. The final return 0 is reachable on the normal successful path.

No statements in the supplied fragments are syntactically unreachable (e.g., code after an unconditional goto/return/break that can never be executed), nor are there branches that are provably impossible given the visible code. Therefore there are no fragments that need further investigation for Rule 2.1 based on the supplied code.
